content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

A zoologist tracks the motion of a penguin over a flat surface of ice. At time <math alttext="t is greater than 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the position of the penguin is <math alttext="the point with coordinates x of t, comma, y of t"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x prime of t, equals the fraction pi t over 2, end fraction, times the cosine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi times t squared, over 4, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y prime of t, equals negative 3, times open parenthesis, 1 minus t, close parenthesis, squared"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours, and <math alttext="x of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in kilometers. At time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the penguin is at position <math alttext="1 comma 3"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Find the acceleration vector of the penguin at time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

A zoologist tracks the motion of a penguin over a flat surface of ice. At time <math alttext="t is greater than 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the position of the penguin is <math alttext="the point with coordinates x of t, comma, y of t"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x prime of t, equals the fraction pi t over 2, end fraction, times the cosine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi times t squared, over 4, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y prime of t, equals negative 3, times open parenthesis, 1 minus t, close parenthesis, squared"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours, and <math alttext="x of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in kilometers. At time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the penguin is at position <math alttext="1 comma 3"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Find the acceleration vector of the penguin at time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b)   Find the <math alttext="y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of the position of the penguin at time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c)   What is the first time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which the penguin’s <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-direction changes? Give a reason for your answer.

(d)   At time <math alttext="t equals k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the penguin has traveled a total distance of 3 kilometers. Write, but do not solve, an equation involving an integral to find the value of <math alttext="k"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></math>.

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.6: (BC ONLY) Solving Motion Problems Using Parametric and Vector-Valued Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
